slidelink.displaytext: 4-H Mission, Vision, Pledge, Symbol, Slogan, & Motto
Play/Pause, Volume Control, and Seeking Within a Slide

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
Welcome to Indiana 4-H Volunteer Orientation. My name is Steve McKinley, State 4-H Volunteer Specialist in Indiana, and I’ll serve as your host for this series. We are excited that you have chosen to pursue volunteer opportunities with the Indiana 4-H Youth Development Program! Thank you for sharing your time and talents with the young people of 4-H.

 

This orientation includes a series of 6 units. The first unit begins with some history of 4-H. Let’s get started!
4-H has been helping youth build skills for over 100 years. The 4-H club movement began in 1902 when corn clubs were organized to give farm boys and girls experiences in “learning by doing.”

Over the years 4-H has grown and changed. It has adapted, and will continue to adapt, to current needs and interests. As a result, today’s 4-H looks much different than it did to its early members.
4-H is a youth development program of the Land Grant University in each state. In Indiana, Extension is based at Purdue University.

4-H is unique because it is the only youth organization tied to the research base of our nation’s land-grant university system and because it is the only federally-authorized, youth-serving organization in the country.

4-H has something for everyone! Indiana 4-H offers programming for students in grades 3-12. Some counties also offer 4-H-related programs for students in grades K-2. 4-H members can participate in 4-H clubs, where groups meet regularly to work on projects, perform community service and develop leadership skills.

 

Indiana 4-H also offers youth leadership, conferences, camping, and other programs at various times throughout the year. Older youth can be involved as youth volunteers in their areas of interest.

Regardless of their method of participation, ALL are 4-H members!

Before you begin your volunteer role, it is important to know a little bit more about what Indiana 4-H stands for, along with some of its symbols and sayings.

Indiana 4-H’s Vision statement reads: “Indiana 4-H Youth Development strives to be the premier, community-based program empowering young people to reach their full potential.”

The purpose, or mission, of Indiana 4-H Youth Development is “to provide real-life educational opportunities that develop young people who positively impact their community and world.”
This mission is accomplished by offering out-of-school non-formal educational programs that excite youth to learn in areas they are interested in; that engage youth in addressing community and youth-related issues; and that encourage youth to reach their full potential in an ever-changing world.

In the pledge, 4-H members pledge their heads to clearer thinking, their hearts to greater loyalty, their hands to larger service and their health to better living for their clubs, their communities their country and their world. 4-H members often recite this pledge, along with the Pledge of Allegiance, at the beginning of meetings.

The 4-H slogan, “Learn by Doing,” sums up the educational design philosophy of the 4-H program. Young people learn best when they are involved in their learning. We will learn more about this in the next session on learning in 4-H.

The 4-H motto,“To Make the Best Better,” is intended to inspire young people to continue to learn and grow, to make their best efforts even better through participating in educational experiences.

You have probably seen the 4-H symbol before, a green four-leaf clover with a white “H” on each leaf representing the four H’s: HEAD, HEART, HANDS and HEALTH.

Knowing the “big picture” of Indiana 4-H, including its connection to Purdue University, and the mission & vision, pledge, motto and slogan, should help you focus your volunteer work in the 4-H program.

We gratefully acknowledge the University of Minnesota Extension for their willingness to share the 4-H Volunteer Orientation series they created. We have modified their original work to be used with 4-H Volunteers in the Indiana 4-H Program.

You’ll also notice the Purdue University Extension statement of inclusion at the bottom of the slide. It is the policy of Purdue University and the Indiana 4-H Program to be inclusive of youth and adults from all backgrounds.

This concludes unit one of the 4-H volunteer orientation series. You’ll now have the opportunity to take a 5-question quiz to test your knowledge about the information we covered in this session. Once you have completed the quiz, please continue on to unit two to learn how we help young people learn in 4-H.
No Audio
No Audio

Welcome back! In this unit we’ll be talking about how young people learn in 4-H.
Our shared goal is for young people to have opportunities to follow their dreams and direct their own learning. Youth learn in different ways and in different places. As a volunteer you play an important role in guiding that learning.

In 4-H we focus on providing for the basic needs of youth to develop and thrive. We call them the four Essential Elements of Positive Youth Development. These elements include belonging, mastery, independence and generosity.

Youth must feel like they BELONG to and are part of the group and are connected to peers and adults in the group.

INDEPENDENCE is met when youth make decisions that affect their lives.

To achieve MASTERY, youth explore ideas and activities and learn skills in a non-threatening atmosphere.

Finally, youth learn that GENEROSITY, or helping others, is a way for them to apply what they have learned, while also connecting to their communities and giving back.

 

Belonging, mastery, independence and generosity--as a volunteer, you will be creating an environment where 4-H youth will learn through these Essential Elements of Positive Youth Development.

Learning is the essential core of any 4-H program. Learning within 4-H can be seen in a variety of ways.

Learning in 4-H is about:

* Gaining knowledge and developing new skills and positive attitudes;

* Developing and using creative talents;

* Learning to make intelligent decisions and to solve problems; and

* Learning to develop a feeling of self-worth, while respecting the rights and privileges of others.

A movement that began in the late 1960s acknowledged the importance of learning and education outside of the formal school setting.

Today, 4-H still contributes to education mostly during out-of-school time.

4-H programs create this out-of-school education through intentional learning linked with community groups, a process called non-formal learning. The physical location of this non-formal learning may be in a number of venues, such as school buildings, community centers, and libraries, among others.

Youth learn most successfully when they use and connect new knowledge to other life experiences. This “learning by doing” model is called Experiential Learning.  Beginning with the experiences of the learners, experiential learning involves learning by doing in five basic steps of a continuous cycle. 

The first step is to do or experience an activity. The second and third steps are to share the experience and process what happened. Fourth, the members identify what they learned and how to connect this new knowledge to real life. Finally, the fifth step asks youth to apply the knowledge they have gained to new or different life situations.

This complete process allows youth to learn new skills, cultivate new attitudes, and develop new ways of thinking. By incorporating Experiential Learning into the 4-H program, we can ensure that learning is self-directed and that young people can evaluate their own learning through processing and applying what they have learned.

As a 4-H volunteer, you will be asked to create learning opportunities where youth learn through this experiential learning model.

Extension staff and other volunteers are available to help you put these steps into action. This concludes the unit on learning in 4-H.
No Audio
No Audio

Welcome to the unit on volunteer roles in 4-H. We hope this will be helpful as you consider how to use your skills as a volunteer.

There are numerous opportunities to volunteer with the 4-H program. We want you to know what volunteer choices are available to you; how you can connect with your local 4-H Extension professional; and what strategies you can use to help create effective teamwork with youth and other volunteers.

 

Your experiences as a volunteer will be most successful when you are placed in a role you like, one that you know something about, or one that you want to learn about.

Ask yourself these questions: What projects or topics do I know well? Are there areas I want to learn about? What organization or management skills do I have or want to develop? How long do I want to be a volunteer--for a year, a month, a season, or just one activity or event? Once you have decided what role best fits your skills and interests, you can choose an area in 4-H that will fit you.

4-H volunteer roles can be grouped into four areas. Within each area there are choices of specific positions. Let's look at those four areas and explore a few of the options. Each of the areas could have positions at the local, county, regional, state or even national level.

Organizational Volunteers:
Organizational volunteers are needed to advise and manage 4-H clubs and committees. These volunteers serve as liaisons among 4-H staff, members, parents, and other volunteers. Leadership positions on various committees may include the chair, secretary, and treasurer, among others. 4-H has opportunities for organizational or management volunteers on all levels and for a wide variety of topics.

Project Volunteers:
4-H members focus on specific areas called projects. If there is a topic in which you have a special interest, becoming a project volunteer may be for you. Project areas range from a wide variety of sciences, to healthy living topics, citizenship, and more. Guiding, teaching and advising youth on a specific area of interest is an exciting part of this role.

Activity Volunteers:
4-H engages youth in a wide variety of educational activities. An activity volunteer provides support and guidance in activity planning and implementation.

In many cases volunteers and youth work together to decide, plan and carry out activities like a family fun night, community service project, club fund raiser, camps, and other activities.

One-Time Volunteers:
4-H needs one-time volunteers to assist with various tasks such as event registration, tracking results, taking pictures, or chaperoning. These are usually short-term volunteer roles. Some may last a few hours, and others, several days.

Youth-Adult Partnerships are all about intentional relationships. This type of partnership happens when both adults and young people are equally engaged in reaching a common goal. This partnership involves real youth participation.

According to a 2009 survey of Tenured Indiana 4-H members, self-responsibility, self-motivation, communication, social skills, and leadership are the five top skills that members gain as a result of the 4-H program. In Indiana 4-H we value quality relationships with adults as a significant opportunity leading to the development of these important life skills. As volunteers, you are called upon to make sure young people have a voice in the program.

Another strategy for effective teamwork is the Shared Leadership Model. All individuals in a group share a sense of responsibility for leadership instead of just one person leading the whole group to success.

The participants take a big-picture approach, not a top-down approach, to plan and accomplish their projects together. Lots of interaction and conversations happen during the shared leadership process.

4-H Extension professionals can help you find opportunities in clubs, afterschool programs, committees, camps and more. You can connect with staff by phone, e-mail or in person.

 

Go to the Purdue Extension Web site (https://extension.purdue.edu/pages/countyoffices.aspx) to find contact information for staff near you.

Ask about role descriptions and task lists. The description will tell you how much time is needed and what specific tasks need to be accomplished.

Knowing how to choose the best role for you, knowing what volunteer opportunities are there for you, learning the concepts of Youth-Adult Partnerships and the Shared Leadership Model on how to develop quality teamwork, and connecting with your local 4-H Extension professional are significant pieces to helping you have a successful volunteer experience.

 

Be sure to visit the Indiana 4-H Web site to find further information and to identify the Extension professional nearest you.

This concludes unit three. The next unit covers stewardship and risk management in Indiana 4-H.
No Audio
No Audio

As adults leading the 4-H program, we play a big part in teaching young people to be good leaders and citizens. It is important for all 4-H volunteers to understand that they are responsible to know and follow the policies that coincide with their volunteer positions. If we are good stewards of the organization and take steps to protect young people, they learn from that.

4-H is owned by the public. It carries a federal tax-exempt status and is designated as “public” because it receives a substantial part of funding from federal, state, and local government sources. This public nature means that staff and volunteers have certain responsibilities that go with the use of the 4-H Name and Emblem—responsibilities that include program, human, and fiscal stewardship.  

Volunteers and members of 4-H clubs, committees, and other groups are responsible not only to their own group, but also to the University and the public at large.

Stewardship:
Stewardship refers to the organization’s resources and is a very important part of 4-H work for volunteers, youth and staff.  Good stewardship is about accountability, responsibility, and setting clear expectations.

Equal Opportunity:

Being a public organization means that programs conducted by 4-H must be open to all regardless of gender, race, sexual orientation, religion, disability, and more. We must ensure that programs have welcoming environments and that they reflect the demographics of our local communities.

Public Investment:
4-H is a publicly owned program, and it has a responsibility to deliver quality youth development experiences for young people. We can usually very easily talk about the value of the program to those members and to their families. But because 4-H is a public investment, it must also deliver “public value”—benefits to community members not directly a part of the program.

In order to deliver public value, we must make sure that we are not simply providing private benefits to individual young people but also providing benefits to the community in which those young people live. Public value might include the work that 4-H members provide to improve their community through service-learning activities, or members developing leadership skills and motivation to support their communities as adults.

Staff members are authorized to use the name and emblem. Chartered 4-H Clubs and 4-H Affiliates, such as 4-H Councils and Fair Boards, can also use the name and emblem and can offer tax exemption status to their donors and contributors.  

Other groups such as the Indiana 4-H Foundation and 4-H camps can use the name and emblem by special agreement.

The use of the 4-H Name and Emblem is protected to the same extent as the Presidential Seal and the Olympic Rings. All 4-H groups must follow federal and state policies and rules regarding its use.

For example, if you raise money in the name of 4-H, you are responsible for protecting the good name of 4-H.  You are responsible for both how the money is raised and how it is used.  

All monies raised using the 4-H name must be used only for 4-H-related activities, education and character building.  

If you are interested in fundraising or entering into any type of contract on behalf of 4-H, you will need to talk with your local 4-H Extension professional regarding appropriate steps to take.

Along with good stewardship practices, 4-H volunteers need to know about and follow good risk management practices. A risk is any uncertainty about an event that threatens an organization’s ability to accomplish its mission.

Risk covers the many unexpected incidents that can happen to the participants, the spectators, the properties, and even the reputation of 4-H.

Considerations for Handling Risk:
As a volunteer, you will be asked to plan for the unexpected as much as possible. While you plan an event or activity, take time to consider the risks and develop a risk management plan. Be sure to follow established program guidelines. Never hesitate to ask for help or for clarification from staff.  And finally, do what a reasonable, cautious person would do.

Volunteer Policies:
There are specific volunteer policies in place to ensure the safety of young people in 4-H. All individuals complete the volunteer screening process before they are approved as 4-H Volunteers. The county 4-H Extension professional will notify you regarding acceptance and placement. Results of the screening are confidential. This volunteer orientation, training for your position, and support from other volunteers and staff all assist in your success with your volunteer position. All volunteers are required to adhere to and annually sign the Adult 4-H Behavioral Expectations.

Supervising Youth:
4-H volunteers typically spend much of their volunteer time with young people. The recommended adult-to-youth ratio for Indiana 4-H programs is 1 adult for every 10 youth. Certain higher-risk activities call for more adults, and chaperoning situations have added age requirements for volunteers. At no time should one adult be left alone with one 4-H member (other than his or her own child). Health information, reports of incidents, and other information that you may receive about individual youth or families must be treated as confidential. However, volunteers should be attentive to the physical and emotional state of all children participating in programs.

Insurance:
Purdue University provides liability insurance for approved 4-H Volunteers who are acting within the scope of their assigned responsibilities. The Indiana 4-H program provides limited accident/injury insurance coverage for all 4-H members and 4-H Volunteers. Individuals are personally responsible for events held on their property.  Insurance for vehicles follows the owner, regardless of who is driving.

Accidents:
No matter how many risk management steps we take, accidents and emergencies can occur. If an emergency occurs with a 4-H member or volunteer, responsible volunteers must ensure that emergency care has been provided. Be sure to contact the county 4-H Extension Professional as soon as is reasonably possible.

We hope you have learned a little more about stewardship, 4-H as the public organization, and important risk management practices in our program that will help you accomplish 4-H’s mission with young people.

 

Please contact your local 4-H Extension Professional if you have additional questions.

 

This concludes unit four of this orientation. Unit five covers Adult Behavioral Expectations of you as a volunteer.
No Audio
No Audio

In the previous session, we talked about risk management associated with the 4-H Program, including ways that we can ensure our 4-H members are provided with a safe environment. A significant part of this topic relates to the 4-H Volunteer Screening Process. In this session, we’ll take a closer look at a set of expectations that each Indiana 4-H Youth Development Volunteer is asked to sign on an annual basis…we call these the Adult Behavioral Expectations, ABE for short.

This session will review and offer a brief explanation of each of these expectations.

The Adult Behavioral Expectations Form is one that you will be asked to sign on an annual basis to continue your participation as a 4-H Volunteer. In addition to agreeing to each of the previously discussed expectations, there will be other boxes for you to check related to a personal liability waiver, certification that you are in compliance with the “Use of Vehicles for University Business” policy, and authorizing a check of the national and state sex and violent offender registries on your behalf.

Be sure to submit your signed ABE to the Extension Office by the requested date.

Expectation 1:
The first expectation of our 4-H Volunteers is to: “Respect, adhere to, and enforce the rules, policies, and guidelines established by the Purdue University Cooperative Extension Service including all laws related to child abuse and substance abuse.”

 

As a 4-H Volunteer, you will represent Purdue University and the Cooperative Extension Service in all of your interactions with others. Guidelines, rules, and policies have been put into place to ensure that we are offering a safe, nurturing environment for all youth. Your willingness and ability to follow these procedures is critical to our success!

 

In Indiana, any citizen who has a reason to believe that a child is a victim of abuse or neglect has the duty to make a report…we are all considered “mandated reporters”. Reports can be made to the Indiana Child Abuse and Neglect Hotline at 1-800-800-5556. All calls are anonymous and confidential. To learn more about characteristics and symptoms of abuse and neglect, visit the National Childhelp Web site: http://www.childhelp.org/pages/hotline-home. For more specific information about the Indiana Department of Child Services, visit: their Web site: http://www.in.gov/dcs/2971.htm. 

Expectation 2:
As with any position, paid or volunteer, there is someone you will report to and who will supervise you.

As a 4-H Adult Volunteer, this person is the 4-H Youth Development Extension Educator. The Educator is the person responsible for the screening, placement, training, and evaluation of all volunteers who serve in the 4-H program. Your ability to interact effectively with your 4-H Educator is critical to the overall success of the 4-H program.

Expectation 3:
There is a lot of information that 4-H Volunteers need to know to effectively perform their volunteer roles.

This series of modules is one example of the orientation and training that will be provided to you on an annual basis.

Your 4-H Extension Educator will schedule additional training opportunities for you to participate in each year. You are encouraged to make these training opportunities a priority as you continue your association as a volunteer in the 4-H program.

Expectation 4:

Many of these expectations relate to the importance of adults serving as a positive role model for youth. Our ability to follow these expectations will enable us to form the important relationships with the youth over a long period of time which is shown to have such a positive impact on the youths’ development.

Expectation 5:
As an adult 4-H Volunteer, you will interact with lots of other people, youth and adults.

There are times that these individuals will not agree with you, or perhaps you will not agree with them. However, it is important at all times to demonstrate courteous, respectful behavior towards all, even if they do not return that same courtesy.

Reasonable conflict management skills include effective conversation and communication skills while interacting with others. Physical violence, bullying behavior, and verbal threats are never appropriate.

Expectation 6:
We expect all individuals who are associated with the 4-H program to be honest and truthful when dealing with others.

Expectation 7:

The 4‐H program is one that is open to all individuals, regardless of their personal backgrounds. 4-H Youth Development highly values diversity in our programs for youth and volunteers. We need to take steps to ensure that all feel welcome and included. It is our responsibility as adults (staff and volunteers) to insure that 4‐H has a welcoming atmosphere to anyone who may wish to participate. Once again, verbal or physical abuse (including any type of bullying behavior) is NEVER appropriate as we work with young people.

Expectation 8:
As adults who are responsible for the well-being and safety of youth, there is NO room for volunteers to use alcohol or illegal drugs while participating in 4-H events or activities.

It is also strongly recommended that no tobacco products (smoke or smokeless) be used while around impressionable 4-H members.


Expectation 9:
Again, as a part of leading by example, the way that we as adults operate our vehicles, equipment, and other pieces of machinery set examples for the youth in our program. This includes our personal vehicles. We need to be especially diligent to follow safe driving practices when we are serving in any capacity with the 4-H program, including the use of seat belts. This also includes times when we may be using equipment around youth, perhaps at the fairgrounds, like mowers, chain saws, fork lifts or front end loaders. We need to ensure we are operating each of these safely!

Expectation 10:
Whether it’s a companion animal, market animal, or breeding stock, we need to encourage all 4-H members and their families to treat all animals humanely and in accordance with the stated policies and guidelines of the 4-H program. Those with market animals need to understand the importance of following these guidelines as their animals will eventually enter the food chain.

Expectation 11:
Technology is all-inclusive…computers, cell phones or smart phones, social media, etc. Our practices while using these important tools are being watched by the 4-H families in our program.

Inappropriate posts on our social media accounts and use of cell phones to send improper messages, videos, or pictures, are examples of things we must avoid as 4-H staff and volunteers!

Expectation 12:
As a 4-H Volunteer, you are the face of the 4-H program in your local community. We rely on you to effectively reach the 4-H members with the information they need to develop the life skills that we promote as a part of the county, state, and national 4-H program.

Personal Liability Waiver:
The first box is a personal liability waiver statement. By checking the box next to this statement, you are acknowledging that participation in 4-H involves certain risks.

You are agreeing that you will not file suit against the university for something that is your responsibility.

By checking this box, you are NOT waiving the liability coverage provided by the University that protects all 4-H Volunteers while they are acting within the scope of their responsibilities.


Purdue Driving Policy:
Any time that you are operating a vehicle on behalf of your volunteer work with the Indiana 4-H Program, you are considered to be on university business.

By checking this box, you are self-verifying that you are in compliance with the university driving policy regulations. These regulations are available from your 4-H Extension Educator. They include moving violations, at-fault crashes, and major offenses such as DUI’s.

If something changes with your driving record during the calendar year, it is your responsibility to notify the 4-H Educator.

Checking this box does not mean that we are asking you to transport 4-H members to and from events.

Offender Registries:

No Audio

This concludes this module on the Adult Behavioral Expectations. For further questions about the ABE, please contact your 4-H Extension Educator.
We thank you for your willingness to accept these expectations and responsibilities as a part of your volunteer role!
You are now ready to move onto the final lesson in this orientation series.
No Audio
No Audio

This is the final unit in the Indiana 4-H Volunteer Orientation series. We would like to thank you again for your interest in serving as a volunteer with Indiana 4-H. As we designed this orientation, we did so in hopes that it would help you get off to a good start and would make your time with the young people in 4-H more meaningful and rewarding.

 

This unit covers the types of local, state and national support you can expect as a volunteer.

Volunteer Partnerships:
Volunteers play an important role within 4-H's organizational structure. This partnership between 4-H staff and screened volunteers provides non-formal educational programs and experiences for thousands of youth across the state.

County Staff:
 At the local level, 4-H Extension Educators work with volunteers, parents, youth and community partners to deliver all aspects of the county 4-H Youth Development program.  Most county Extension offices also have Extension Educators focusing on areas such as Agriculture and Natural Resources, Health and Human Sciences, and Community Development. County support staff provide assistance to these Educators.

Please take time to introduce yourself to the 4-H Educator and County Extension staff.  Become familiar with the county Extension office location and obtain the address, phone number, web address, and e-mail addresses of staff members.

Purdue Extension Service:

Indiana 4-H is housed at Purdue University’s West Lafayette campus as a part of the Purdue Extension Service.

Campus-based Extension faculty and specialists are responsible for coordinating the state-wide Indiana 4-H Program with the County 4-H Extension Educators. It takes a lot of people working together to provide youth with positive 4-H experiences!

The State 4-H Program Leader, along with other faculty and staff, work together to apply knowledge and research to program development and evaluation while supporting 4-H staff and volunteers in every county.

4-H is supported by a combination of federal, state and county funds. Substantial support also comes from private sources on local, state and national levels.

The National 4-H Council and the Indiana 4-H Foundation are not-for-profit organizations that support the 4-H Youth Development Program by working to acquire resources.

In addition to people available to support your volunteer work, a number of web-based and print resources exist. There is a wealth of 4-H information online.

Indiana 4-H Website:
A good place to start is the Indiana 4-H page.

Here you'll find information on project resources for youth and volunteers, links to 4-H events and a calendar with state and regional opportunities.  There are also links to connect to county 4-H Websites for local information.

Indiana 4-H Volunteer Website:
Specific volunteer information is available on the Indiana 4-H Volunteer page. On this page, you will find several volunteer training resources, along with lessons plans and supporting materials to lead with your 4-H members.

National 4-H Website:
Volunteers can connect with 4-H on a national level.  The National 4-H Council has resources about programs, grants, volunteers and research. 4-H Web sites are updated regularly, so be sure to visit often.

If web access is an issue, libraries, friends or family, or the county Extension office may be able to provide Internet access.

National 4-H Source Book:
The National 4-H Council Source Book offers a multitude of 4-H items for sale.  It is the source for purchasing project resources that have been reviewed and recommended for 4-H use. 

The Source Book is available in print and also online at www.4-HMall.org.

There are multiple ways to receive communication about the 4-H program. Your primary source of communication will come through your County Extension Office.

A statewide newsletter, 4-H Volunteer Vision, is also published monthly, containing some information and programming suggestions for you to share with your 4-H members and their families.

Indiana 4-H is also on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and Flickr. Like or Follow us to keep up-to-date on 4-H information.

Other communication may happen via email, text, blog, phone or direct mail. Talk to 4-H program staff about the best way for you to receive information.

We want you to be successful in, and satisfied with, your volunteer role.

Understanding the organizational structure and staff roles as well as the available people, print and online resources will help you better support the 4-H mission. If you have further questions, please contact your local 4-H Extension professional for more information.

Thank you for your participation in this Indiana 4-H Orientation series!
